MKILLUM

public static final java.lang.String MKILLUM
mkillum flag to add to material name, will be cought up by exporter the normal of the face must point towards the inside note: forbidden string for material names usage example: Radiance.setMaterial(myObj,Radiance.GLASS+Radiance.MKILLUM);

Method Detail

exportSky

public static void exportSky(java.lang.String path)

accuracy

public static void accuracy(int level)
simple and fast choice of parameters level=0 -> min accuracy ... level=5 -> max accuracy though non-zero -aa and -ar The following is extracted from p34 of http://luminance.londonmet.ac.uk/learnix/docs/radiance_tutorial.pdf Parameter Description Min Fast Accur Very Accur Max -ab ambient bounces 0 0 2 5 8 -aa ambient accuracy 0.5 0.2 0.15 0.08 0 -ar ambient resolution 8 32 128 512 0 -ad ambient divisions 0 32 512 2048 4096 -as ambient super-samples 0 32 256 512 1024 min for fastest, crudest rendering. It is not necessarily the smallest value numerically. fast for reasonably fast rendering. accur for reasonably accurate rendering (artificial lighting) very accur for highly accurate rendering or complicated scenes (daylighting) max for the ultimate in accuracy. Avoid using the "max" setting for -aa and -ar. This disables optimisation and can be very expensive in terms of rendering time. Parameter Artifact Solution -ab lighting in shadows too flat increment value -av overall light level seems too high/low decrease/increase value -aa uneven shading boundaries in shadows decrease value by 25% -ar shading wrong in some areas double or quadruple value -ad "splotches" of light double value -as "splotches" of light increase to half of -ad setting

addMaterialPlastic

public static void addMaterialPlastic(java.lang.String name,
                                      float r,
                                      float g,
                                      float b,
                                      float spec,
                                      float rough)
add plastic-based user defined material example: # light blue void plastic LightBlue 0 0 5 .7 .7 1 .15 .02 http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
r - - red 0 to 1
g - - green 0 to 1
b - - blue 0 to 1
spec - - specularity 0 to .07
rough - - roughness 0 to .2

b - - blue 0 to 1
spec - - specularity .5 to 1

addMaterialMirror

public static void addMaterialMirror(java.lang.String name,
                                     java.lang.String material,
                                     float r,
                                     float g,
                                     float b)
add user defined mirror material example: # light blue mirror void mirror LightBlue 1 DarkGrey 0 3 .7 .7 1 http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
material - - visible material of the mirror, use "void" if not defined
r - - red 0 to 1
g - - green 0 to 1
b - - blue 0 to 1

addMaterialLight

public static void addMaterialLight(java.lang.String name,
                                    float r,
                                    float g,
                                    float b)
add user defined light material defined by RGB radiance value (watts/steradian/m2) example: # light blue light void light LightBlueUser 0 0 3 70 70 100 http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
r - - red output brightness 0 to inf
g - - green output brightness 0 to inf
b - - blue output brightness 0 to inf

addMaterialGlass

public static void addMaterialGlass(java.lang.String name,
                                    float r,
                                    float g,
                                    float b)
add user defined glass material The only specification required is the transmissivity at normal incidence. Transmissivity is the amount of light not absorbed in one traversal of the material. Transmittance -- the value usually measured -- is the total light transmitted through the pane including multiple reflections. To compute transmissivity (tn) from transmittance (Tn) use: tn = (sqrt(.8402528435+.0072522239*Tn*Tn)-.9166530661)/.0036261119/Tn Standard 88% transmittance glass has a transmissivity of 0.96. http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
r - - red transmissivity 0 to 1
g - - green transmissivity 0 to 1
b - - blue transmissivity 0 to 1

addMaterialDielectric

public static void addMaterialDielectric(java.lang.String name,
                                         float r,
                                         float g,
                                         float b,
                                         float n,
                                         float hart)
add dielectric-based user defined material http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
r - - red transmission 0 to 1
g - - green transmission 0 to 1
b - - blue transmission 0 to 1
n - - refractive index 1 to 2
hart - - hartmann constant -20 to 30

addMaterialIllum

public static void addMaterialIllum(java.lang.String name,
                                    java.lang.String material,
                                    float r,
                                    float g,
                                    float b)
add user defined secondary light source material based on default WindowDist window distribution function example: # secondary light source WindowDist illum WindowIllum 1 WindowGlass 0 3 .88 .88 .88 http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/ray.html#Materials http://radsite.lbl.gov/radiance/refer/Notes/materials.html

Parameters:
name -
material - - visible material of the secondary light source, use "void" if not defined
r - - red transmission 0 to 1
g - - green transmission 0 to 1
b - - blue transmission 0 to 1
